metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Acute thrombosis of an aortic prosthetic graft in a patient with severe COVID-19 related pneumonia Acute thrombosis of an aortic prosthetic graft in a patient with severe COVID-19 related Corresponding author

abstract.text: Purpose 25 COVID19 infection has been reported to be related with an increased risk of thrombotic 26 complications due to hypercoagulability state and inflammation. At the moment no reports are 27 available regarding thrombosis of prosthetic vascular grafts. We present the case of a patient with 28 COVID19-related pneumonia, who suffered from the acute thrombosis of a previously implanted 29 aortic graft. 30 Case report 31 A 67-year old male patient, undergone open repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a 32 bifurcated graft six years before, was admitted to the Emergency Department with high fever for a 33 week without cough or dyspnea. Thoracic ultrasound showed signs of bilateral interstitial 34 pneumonia and the Sars-Cov-2 swab was positive. Antiretroviral therapy and prophylactic low 35 molecular weight heparin treatment were initiated. Due to the progressive impairment of respiratory 36 function, the patient was intubated after eight days from the admission. The day after he showed 37 signs of bilateral acute limb ischemia. A duplex ultrasound demonstrated the complete thrombosis 38 of the aortic graft without flow at the femoral level. An urgent angio-computed tomography (CT) 39 scan for revascularization purpose was requested, but the patient died upon the arrival in 40 radiological suite. 41 Conclusion 42

body_text.text: This finding can explain why thrombosis did not occur immediately at hospitalization but after a 107 few days, in the moment when the inflammatory response in the patient was hyperactivated, as 108 reported in the late stages of the infection. 8 The patient was on heparin therapy at the prophylactic 109 dose of 50 IU/kg, which has not been enough to prevent the acute thrombotic event. 9 It is 110 reasonable to think that, if a patient with Sars-Cov-2 infection has a higher thrombotic risk, this will 111 be much higher in a patient with a vascular prosthesis. For this reason, it can be suggested that 112 patients with vascular prosthesis could be considered a selected subgroup, in which, in case of 113 COVID19, it is probably necessary to start an aggressive treatment with heparin at therapeutic 114 dosage. Acute aortic thrombosis is a condition associated with high mortality. Even in our case the 115 patient, who already showed very bad general condition due to the COVID19, died. If the general

FIGREF0.text: has been reported to be related with an increased risk of thrombotic 26 complications due to hypercoagulability state and inflammation. At the moment no reports are 27 available regarding thrombosis of prosthetic vascular grafts. We present the case of a patient with 28 COVID19-related pneumonia, who suffered from the acute thrombosis of a previously implanted 29 aortic graft.

FIGREF1.text: -year old male patient, undergone open repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a 32 bifurcated graft six years before, was admitted to the Emergency Department with high fever for a 33 week without cough or dyspnea. Thoracic ultrasound showed signs of bilateral interstitial 34 pneumonia and the Sars-Cov-2 swab was positive. Antiretroviral therapy and prophylactic low 35 molecular weight heparin treatment were initiated. Due to the progressive impairment of respiratory 36 function, the patient was intubated after eight days from the admission. The day after he showed 37 signs of bilateral acute limb ischemia. A duplex ultrasound demonstrated the complete thrombosis 38 of the aortic graft without flow at the femoral level. An urgent angio-computed tomography (CT) 39 scan for revascularization purpose was requested, but the patient died upon the arrival in 40 radiological suite. 41 Conclusion 42 Acute thrombosis of vascular prosthetic grafts is a possible, catastrophic complication of COVID19 43 infection. In COVID19 patients with prosthetic graft an aggressive antithrombotic treatment could 44 be considered to prevent such an event.

FIGREF2.text: increasing number of reports on thrombotic complications in patients with COVID19 49 infection. 1-2 In particular, arterial thrombosis account for about 4% of thromboembolic 50 complications during COVID19, but at the moment there are no reported cases of prosthetic graft 51 occlusion. In the present paper we describe the case of a patient with COVID19-related pneumonia, 52 who suffered from the acute thrombosis of a previously implanted aortic graft. At the moment of 53 hospital admission, the patient gave his consent to the treatment of personal data, including the 54 possibility to use them for scientific purposes.

FIGREF3.text: -year old male entered the Emergency Room (ER) in March 23rd 2020, with high fever (100,4 58 °F) for a week, but no cough or dyspnea. The patient suffered for years of arterial hypertension in 59 treatment with ace-inhibitor and calcium channel blocker and in 2014 he had undergone open repair 60 of a 60 mm abdominal aortic aneurysm with a 14/7 mm bifurcated aorto-bi-iliac dacron graft. Since 61 then he was in treatment with 100 mg/die of acetylsalicylic acid. In January 2019 a duplex 62 ultrasound (DUS) exam had demonstrated the patency of the graft, the absence of pseudoaneurysms 63 or stenosis, and a normal flow of the femoral-popliteal-tibial axis in both legs. At the admission, the 64 abdomen was treatable, femoral and peripheral pulses normally present at both legs. Oxygen 65 saturation (SaO 2 ) was 89% in air, Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) in air showed pH 7.47, PaCO2 29, 66 PaO2 57, Hb 15, SaO2 89.7, HCO3-22. The thoracic ultrasound demonstrated moderate bilateral 67 B-lines without pleural effusion. At the thoracic RX interstitial thickenings in the medium and basal therapy with lopinavir/ritonavir and hydroxychloroquine was administrated. Moreover, 71 thrombotic prophylaxis with subcutaneous enoxaparin (50 IU/kg per day) was initiated. In the 72 following days the ABG values got worse, with a drop of Horowitz Index (HI) under 100 despite 73 the ventilation with reservoir. On march 25 th , due to the worsening of respiratory exchanges, the 74 patient was transferred to Intensive Care Unit (ICU). At that moment he had fever and dyspnea. 75 Blood tests showed Fibrinogen 432 mg/dL, D-Dimer 754 ng/mL, IL-6 19.6 pg/mL and PCR 107 76 mg/L. CPAP ventilation was initiated (PEEP 8-FiO2 80%), therapy with lopinavir/ritonavir and 77 hydroxychloroquine was continued, and the patient also started, in the absence of contraindications, 78 the therapeutic protocol currently used in our hospital with methylprednisolone 80 mg and 79 tocilizumab (2 doses). Respiratory exchanges got worse (HI 64) and the patient was intubated and 80 pronated immediately. On march 31 st the patient suddenly showed pallor and hypothermia of both 81 legs, with moire starting from the transverse umbilical line. Femoral and peripheral pulses were 82 absent in both legs. Blood tests showed D-dimer 104822 ng/mL, CPK 1124 U/L, myoglobin 33327 83 ng/mL, LDH 1124 U/L, IL-6 >200 pg/mL. Continuous intravenous administration of sodium 84 heparin at anticoagulant dosage (1000 IU/h) was immediately started. A bedside DUS showed the 85 patency of the suprarenal aorta and of the renal arteries and the complete thrombosis of the aortic 86 graft without detectable blood-flow at the femoral level. An angio-computed tomography (CT) scan 87 was immediately requested for an intended attempt of hybrid revascularization with bilateral 88 femoral surgical access and thrombectomy under fluoroscopic guide. However, upon the arrival in 89 the radiological suite the patient presented severe hypotension not respondent to the infusion of 90 amine at high dosage, bradycardia and, later, pulseless electrical activity. Despite cardiopulmonary 91 resuscitation the patient presented flatline and the death was declared.

FIGREF4.text: is associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic complications due to 95 inflammation, stasis and hypercoagulable status. 4,5 The majority of the reported cases deal with 96 venous thromboembolism, whereas few arterial thromboses are reported. 1,6 Moreover, at the 97 moment no cases regarding thrombosis of prosthesis and vascular stents are reported. We reported 98 the case of acute thrombosis of a prosthetic aortic graft in a patient with severe COVID19 related 99 infection. Aortic graft thrombosis is an uncommon event, accounting for less than 1% of all aortic 100 reconstructions, and it is favored by concurrent conditions as proximal and distal anastomosis 101 stenosis or severe occlusive disease of the outflow vessels. 7 In the present case, the patient did not 102 show any signs of distal hypoperfusion at the admission, and the most recent outpatient examination 103 had demonstrated normal patency of graft without proximal or distal significant disease. As a 104 consequence, the only possible explanation for such an event was hypercoagulability and 105 inflammation, as supported by the laboratory tests, showing very high levels of D-Dimer and IL-6.
